results.title: Crash zone. Vol. 4. Season 2. Eps 01-05
results.creator_credit: Bernadette O'Mahony, Steve Steve Jodrell, Julie McSwiney, Ray Boseley, David Swann, Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crash zone”.
Episode 1: The second season of the series opens with Catalyst on the brink of financial ruin. The kids find an electronic solution to the company’s woes. Episode 2. An inventor brings radical 3-D classes to Catalyst and Alex and the team must select the perfect game for showcasing them to the world. Episode 3: The lure of a program that can order all the free stuff from the Net automatically inspires Marcello’s latest brainwave. Episode 4: The kids are torn between their principles and their allegiance to Alex when they go on strike for better conditions. Episode 5: Mike becomes drawn in to a violent game on the Net after he breaks up with Pi. Things get out of hand when ‘Damon’, an evil character from the game follows Mike into the real world. Cast includes Paul Pantano, Cassandra Magrath, Nikolai Nikolaeff, Frances Wang, Damien Bodie, Nicki Wendt and Matthew Parkinson. Teaching resources can be found at: http://www.actf.com.au/learning_centre_new/Learning_frameset.htm Accompanying website at: www.crashzone.tv

results.title: Crash zone. Vol. 3. Season 1. Eps 10-13
results.creator_credit: Patricia Edgar, Stephen Johnson, Pino Amenta, Ray Boseley, Esben Storm, Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crash zone”.
Episode 10: When a stranger arrives at Catalyst with a new game he claims to have invented, Alex is eager to invest in it. When Mike discovers the game is stolen he teams up with Pi to save Alex from embarrassment. Episode 11: Marcello and Mike are forced to face some home truths about people they have idolised. Episode 12: After Marcello throws Catalyst into panic when he hacks into the computer system, the rest of the kids have to decide where to place their allegiances - with Marcello or Alex. Episode 13: When Virgil is ‘captured’ by opposing games company Sunijim, Marcello attempts to redeem himself in Alex’s eyes by rescuing him. After he also runs into difficulties the friends use their computer skills to save them both and reunite the Crash Zone team. Cast includes Paul Pantano, Cassandra Magrath, Nikolai Nikolaeff, Frances Wang, Damien Bodie, Nicki Wendt and Matthew Parkinson. Teaching resources can be found at: http://www.actf.com.au/learning_centre_new/Learning_frameset.htm Accompanying website at: www.crashzone.tv

results.title: Crash zone. Vol. 1. Season 1. Eps 01-05
results.creator_credit: Patricia Edgar, Stephen Johnson, Pino Amenta, Ray Boseley, Esben Storm, Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crash zone”.
Episode 1: Mike, Pi, Bec, Marcello and Ram all decipher a coded message on the net which leads them to Catalyst software where they are offered the job of their dreams - testing video games after school. Episode 2: While testing a video game the kids encounter Virgil, an artificial intelligence that lives inside the Internet, and uncover his origins. Episode 3: When Alex, the head of Catalyst, loses her necklace, the gang comes under suspicion. At the same time Marcello’s little sister is lost on the streets, giving the friends two cases to solve. Episode 4: Master inventor and the youngest of the group Ram, gets more than he bargained for when he sells one of his adventures to a strange girl. Episode 5: A computer virus invades Catalyst threatening the company’s computer systems. The team is tense after Mike fails to defend Bec when his friends make racist comments to her. Cast includes Paul Pantano, Cassandra Magrath, Nikolai Nikolaeff, Frances Wang, Damien Bodie, Nicki Wendt and Matthew Parkinson. Teaching resources can be found at: http://www.actf.com.au/learning_centre_new/Learning_frameset.htm Accompanying website at: www.crashzone.tv

results.title: Crash zone. Vol. 2. Season 1. Eps 06-09
results.creator_credit: Patricia Edgar, Stephen Johnson, Pino Amenta, Ray Boseley, Esben Storm, Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crash zone”.
Episode 6: When Bec begins a ‘Net romance’ the boys are sceptical. Their worst fears are realised when they discover that it is Virgil, their A.I. friend that is wooing her. Episode 7: Bec and Pi have differences of opinion when they design a game for girls about teenage romance. The resulting mess causes the team to acknowledge they still have a lot to learn about emotions and life. Episode 8: When a reporter arrives at Catalyst to do a story on the testers, they have suspicions she may be a spy. Pi, who has led the gang to believe she is a street kid, is unmasked when her mother tracks her to the company. Cast includes Paul Pantano, Cassandra Magrath, Nikolai Nikolaeff, Frances Wang, Damien Bodie, Nicki Wendt and Matthew Parkinson. Teaching resources can be found at: http://www.actf.com.au/learning_centre_new/Learning_frameset.htm Accompanying website at: www.crashzone.tv

results.title: Zvenigora (Musical Soundtrack)
results.brief_description:
Dovzhenko’s most audacious film combines ancient folklore with modern events in ranging over many centuries of Ukrainian history with a political aim of obliquely linking modern revolutionary Ukraine with its distant past. For Dovzhenko the fresco-like narrative was what he described as ‘a catalogue of my creative possibilities’. The four part structure with a strange quest for treasure at its centre, incorporates a series of bracketing devices to enclose such eccentric episodes as those involving a vampire-like monk, midsummer rituals on the river and a toytown battle. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Alexander Dovzhenko ; writer, Mikhail Johansen, Yuri Yurtik ; photography, Boris Zavelev.
Cast: Mikola Nademsky, Semyon Svashenko, Alexander Podorozhny.

results.title: Zvenigora
results.brief_description: Zvenigora is a complex yet compelling fantasy, presenting the story of a group of Russian peasants and their strong ties with the earth through a series of simple yet strikingly beautiful images. Spanning a period of a thousand years, the film relates the eternal struggle between needing to nurture the land and wanting to strip it of its treasures. A wealth of magical images fill and frame the landscape, from the wizard monk whose death-like countenance terrorises the invaders to the man who advertises his own suicide as theatrical entertainment then absconds with the box office takings. This film is as much a parable about human nature as it is a representation of the struggles of the Russian peasantry, using technical experiments similar to those of Georges Melies to embellish the transcendental nature of the subject. Zvenigora is the fourth film by Russian film master Alexander Dovzhenko, who began his career in film in 1926 after working as both a cartoonist and painter. Despite negative critical reaction to Zvenigora, it was the forerunner of his more celebrated films Arsenal (1929), Zemlya (1930), and Ivan (1932), which perpetuated his interest in honouring the lives and struggles of peasants, and served as a tribute to his heritage as a man of the Ukraine.

results.title: Zulu Zion
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Mischa Scorer and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this visit to South Africa Ronald Eyre looks at the ways Christianity has evolved into an almost completely different religion, with an emphasis on dreams, purification, healing and the power of the holy spirit. Black Africans separated from the land search to replace these roots in God and the three different Christian sects which are explored here - the Zionists, the Lutherans and the Nazarites, all in their different ways have combined traditional African religion with Christianity. A fascinating look at how two different religions can merge and evolve into something quite unique and alive.

results.title: Zulu
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Joseph E. Levine, Diamond Films, Sir Stanley Baker and Cy Endfield
results.brief_description: One of the most popular British films of the 1960’s, “Zulu” is based on the true story of the defence of Rorke’s Drift in 1879. In this battle, 1200 men of the South Wales Borderers confronted four thousand attacking Zulu warriors. A stunning, historically accurate, battle picture starring the great British actors Stanley Baker, Jack Hawkins and Michael Caine in his first screen role. A movie of “epic” proportions, the long and bloody battle is depicted in meticulous detail. The Zulus, who had never seen a motion picture, were shown an old Roy Rogers western to assist their performance. The Zulu chief is played by the real-life Chief Buthelezzi.

results.title: Zorba the Greek
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Michael Cacoyannis
results.brief_description: After inheriting a mine in Crete, a young English writer (Alan Bates) goes to the Mediterranean island to inspect his property. There he meets Alexis Zorba (Anthony Quinn), a gregarious Greek who persuades Basil that he can help him re-establish the mine. Their encounters with the village community, including an ageing French coquette Hortense (Lila Kedrova) and a beautiful widow (Irene Papas), are by turns amusing and horrifying. Based on the novel by Nikos Kazantzakis.
